body.p: Numerical solution of a nonlinear advance-delay-differential equation from nerve conduction theory
Henjin Chi, Jonathan Bell and Brian Hassard

Abstract. A functional differential equation which is nonlinear and involves forward and backward deviating arguments is solved numerically. The equation models conduction in a myelinated nerve axon in which the myelin completely insulates the membrane, so that the potential change jumps from node to node. The equation is of first order with boundary values given at ğ‘¡plus-or-minust=Â±âˆt=\pm\infty. The problem is approximated via a difference scheme which solves the problem on a finite interval by utilizing an asymptotic representation at the endpoints, cubic interpolation and iterative techniques to approximate the delays, and a continuation method to start the procedure. The procedure is tested on a class of problems which are solvable analytically to access the schemeâ€™s accuracy and stability, then applied to the problem that models propagation in a myelinated axon. The solutionâ€™s dependence on various model parameters of physical interest is studied. This is the first numerical study of myelinated nerve conduction in which the advance and delay terms are treated explicitly.

Key words: Functional differential equation â€“ Advance-delay-diflerential equation â€“ Continuation method â€“ Nerve conduction â€“ Finite difference method â€“ Numerical functional diflerential equation
1. Introduction
In this paper we solve a nonlinear, mixed-delay differential equation defined on the real line. The problem has the form

where ğ‘£ğ‘¡vâ¢(t)v(t) represents the transmembrane potential at a node in our simplified model for nerve conduction in a myelinated axon. The internodal delay ğœÏ„,\tau, represents the reciprocal of the speed of the potential wave as it propagates down the axon. This constant ğœÏ„\tau is unknown a priori and must be found simultaneously with ğ‘£ğ‘¡vâ¢(t)v(t) . The constants R and C represent axoplasmic nodal resistivity and nodal capacity, respectively. ~ğ¹F~\tilde{F} includes the model current-voltage relation.

In Sect. 2 we give a derivation of the model. In Sects. 3-6 we describe a numerical scheme with local truncation error of order four for solving (1.1). The problem is solved on a finite interval, with asymptotic approximations used outside the interval. The Eq. (1.1) is discretized by using a five point formula for the time derivative terms, and cubic interpolation for the delayed and advanced terms. We use finite difference methods to set up a system of ğ‘2N+2N+2 equations to solve ğ‘2N+2N+2 unknowns. Since the function ~ğ¹F~\tilde{F} is nonlinear, the Newton-Raphson iteration procedure was used to approach the solution. Because it is a nonlinear system, we need an initial guess of the solution. Using a test problem, which is solvable analytically, and a continuation method, we obtain the solution of the desired problem by using the exact solution of the test problem to start the continuation method. In Sect. 7 we present numerical results of the method. We test the accuracy of the method on several test problems. Then we apply the method to our specific model. We determine the dependence of the solution ğ‘£ğ‘¡vâ¢(t)v(t) , and ğœÏ„\tau, on the various parameters b,a,R and C, and interpret the results.
2. Model formulation

Myelination of an axon allows it to conduct neuroelectric signals by exciting only a small percentage of membrane exposed to the extracellular medium at the node of Ranvier (see Fig. 1), particularly in the peripheral nervous system 316. This permits transmission at greatly reduced energy expenditure and higher speeds than comparably sized unmyelinated axons 16.

Because myelin has a higher resistance and lower capacitance than membrane, when the membrane is depolarized at a node, it tends not to depolarize the adjacent region of membrane, but instead it appears to jump to the next node to excite the membrane there 16 (called saltatory conduction). There have been a number of papers associated with mathematical modeling and examining various quantitative relations between model parameters 123121415. Most analytical studies have formulated a mathematical model from an electrical circuit model which assumes what we call the pure saltatory conduction (PSC) hypothesis, namely, the myelin has such high resistance, and low capacitance that it completely insulates the membrane.

In a PSC model all excitable behavior is at the nodes and no transmembrane current is allowed through the internode. Consider the electrical circuit model given by Fig. 2. The superscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–superscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜ğ‘œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘œri,ro,Vki,Vko,jki,jkor^{i},r^{o},V_{k}^{i},V_{k}^{o},j_{k}^{i},j_{k}^{o} represent, respectively, the longitudinal resistances, longitudinal membrane potentials and currents across the kth node 13. The superscript â€iâ€ (for inner) refers to axoplasmic quantities, the super- script â€oâ€ (for outer) refers to extracellar quantities, and the superscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘šjkmj_{k}^{m} represents membrane current at the ğ‘˜thkâ¢thk\mathrm{t}\mathrm{h} node. Applying Kirchhoffâ€™s and Ohmâ€™s law to the circuit model, we then obtain:

superscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜1ğ‘œ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜ğ‘œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜1ğ‘œ-roâ¢jkm=Vk-1o-2â¢Vko+Vk+1o-r^{o}j_{k}^{m}=V_{k-1}^{o}-2V_{k}^{o}+V_{k+1}^{o}.

Now let ğ‘…superscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–superscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘œR=ri+roR=r^{i}+r^{o}subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜ğ‘œVk=Vki-VkoV_{k}=V_{k}^{i}-V_{k}^{o}. Then by subtracting (2.1b) from (2.1a), we obtain the following equation at the kth node:
ğ‘…superscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜12subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜1Râ¢jkm=Vk-1-2â¢Vk+Vk+1Rj_{k}^{m}=V_{k-1}-2V_{k}+V_{k+1}.
Now, as in 13, we suppose that the membrane current for the node is the sum of parallel capacity and ionic currents, thus giving
superscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ¶ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘‡ğ¼subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜jkm=Câ¢dâ¢Vkdâ¢T+Iâ¢(Vk)j_{k}^{m}=C\frac{dV_{k}}{dT}+I(V_{k}) .
By combining Eqs. (2.2) and (2.3), we obtain the following difference-differential equation model of transmembrane potential subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜VkV_{k} at the kth node:
subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜12subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜1ğ‘…ğ¶ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘‡ğ¼subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜Vk-1-2â¢Vk+Vk+1R=Câ¢dâ¢Vkdâ¢T+Iâ¢(Vk)\frac{V_{k-1}-2V_{k}+V_{k+1}}{R}=C\frac{dV_{k}}{dT}+I(V_{k}) .

In addition to the PSC hypothesis and the assumption concerning parallel capacity and ionic currents, the circuit model assumes that the axon is infinite in extent, that axon cross-sectional variations in potential (hence current) are negligible and that nodes are point sources of excitation, electrically identical and uniformly spaced.

At this point, various models can be studied depending upon what is chosen for the current-voltage expression ğ¼ğ‘‰Iâ¢(V)I(V) . ğ¼ğ‘‰Iâ¢(V)I(V) may also depend upon other â€state variablesâ€ satisfying their own voltage-dependent dynamics. For example, using a linear current-voltage relation, Landahl 12 showed there was a critical inter- nodal length and diameter maximizing conduction velocity, while McNeal 14 computed strength-duration curves using a more physiologically realistic I. A more realistic model of the nodal membrane dynamics is one by Frankenhaeuser and Huxley 8, where their current-voltage relation ğ¼ğ‘‰Iâ¢(V)I(V) is the sum of three ion-specific current densities and a residual current. We choose the well known FitzHugh-Nagumo model 9 at each node since it has been used in studies of unmyelinated axons and has proven to be quite useful in exploring threshold behavior, action potential and repetitive activity. With FitzHugh-Nagumo dynamics for the nodal membrane, without a recovery term, system (2.4) becomes

subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜12subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜1ğ‘…ğ¶ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘‡ğ¹subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜Vk-1-2â¢Vk+Vk+1R=Câ¢dâ¢Vkdâ¢T-Fâ¢(Vk)\displaystyle\frac{V_{k-1}-2V_{k}+V_{k+1}}{R}=C\frac{dV_{k}}{dT}-F(V_{k}) .

ğ¹ğ‘‰Fâ¢(V)F(V) is a current-voltage relation that has the nonlinear cubic behavior below: ğ¹superscriptğ¶10ğ‘„FâˆˆC1â¢[0,Q]F\in C^{1}[0,\ Q]; ğ¹0ğ¹ğ‘„0Fâ¢(0)=Fâ¢(Q)=0F(0)=F(Q)=0; ğ¹ğ‘¥0Fâ¢(x)<0F(x)<0 for 0ğ‘¥ğ‘ƒ0<x<P0<x<P, superscriptğ¹â€²00Fâ€²â¢(0)<0F^{\prime}(0)<0;
ğ¹ğ‘¥0Fâ¢(x)>0F(x)>0 for formulae-sequenceğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ‘„superscriptğ¹â€²ğ‘„0P<x<Q,Fâ€²â¢(Q)<0P<x<Q,F^{\prime}(Q)<0.

ğ‘‰0Vâ‰¡0V\equiv 0 represents the rest potential, the threshold potential is represented by ğ‘‰ğ‘ƒVâ‰¡P,V\equiv P, and ğ‘‰ğ‘„Vâ‰¡QV\equiv Q represents the fully-activated potential level of the node. Some analytical results for the model wilh recovery are given in Bell 2. Below we concentrate on one representative function satisfying (2.6), namely ğ¹ğ‘¥ğµğ‘¥ğ‘„ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘ƒFâ¢(x)=Bâ¢xâ¢(Q-x)â¢(x-P)F(x)=Bx(Q-x)(x-P) . Now assume that a suprathreshold stimulus initiates a propagated action potential which then travels from node to node down the axon. Longitudinal circulating currents are set up which excite successive nodes. Because of the uniformity assumption, each succeeding node responds exactly as its predecessor except for an internodal time delay italic-Ï•0Ï•>0\phi>0; that is
subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘—1ğ‘‡italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘—ğ‘‡Vj+1â¢(T+Ï•)=Vjâ¢(T)V_{j+1}(T+\phi)=V_{j}(T) for all ğ‘—ğ‘jâˆˆZj\in Z, all T

If l is the internodal length, the speed is given by ğ‘£ğ‘™italic-Ï•v=l/Ï•v=l/\phi. One object here is to gain an understanding of how italic-Ï•Ï•\phi (and therefore v) depends on other model parameters. Because of (2.7) we can consider the behavior at a single node, since the behavior at any other node is just a time translation. Letting ğ‘‰ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜ğ‘‡Vâ¢(T)=Vkâ¢(T)V(T)=V_{k}(T) , then V satisfies
with formulae-sequenceğ‘‰0ğ‘‰ğ‘„Vâ¢(-âˆ)=0,Vâ¢(+âˆ)=QV(-\infty)=0,V(+\infty)=Q.

This problem is a nonlinear, mixed-delay, boundary value problem defined on the real line in which italic-Ï•Ï•\phi is unknown a priori. Before proceeding, we want to reduce parameters by nondimensionalizing (2.8). To nondimensionalize the model, let
ğ‘¡ğ‘‡ğ‘…ğ¶t=TRâ¢Ct=\frac{T}{RC}, ğœitalic-Ï•ğ‘…ğ¶Ï„=Ï•Râ¢C\tau=\frac{\phi}{RC}, ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘‰ğ‘‡ğ‘„vâ¢(t)=Vâ¢(T)Qv(t)=\frac{V(T)}{Q}.
With these substitutions, the model becomes
ğ‘‘ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘‘ğ‘¡ğ‘“ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğœ2ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğœdâ¢vâ¢(t)dâ¢t=fâ¢(vâ¢(t))+vâ¢(t-Ï„)-2â¢vâ¢(t)+vâ¢(t+Ï„)\displaystyle\frac{dv(t)}{dt}=f(v(t))+v(t-\tau)-2v(t)+v(t+\tau) ,
with formulae-sequenceğ‘£0ğ‘£1vâ¢(-âˆ)=0,vâ¢(+âˆ)=1v(-\infty)=0,v(+\infty)=1, where we obtain
formulae-sequenceğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘„0ğ‘1a=P/Q,0<a<1a=P/Q,0<a<1, and formulae-sequenceğ‘â‹…ğ‘…ğµsuperscriptğ‘„2ğ‘0b=Râ‹…Bâ‹…Q2,b>0b=R\cdot B\cdot Q^{2},b>0.
Notice in (2.9), the scaling here is not the usual scaling in a cable model for nonmyelinated axon, but it serves our purpose.

In the nondimensional model, a is the threshold potential, ğœÏ„\tau is the nondimensional time delay, and b is related to the strength of the ionic current density. Since the current-voltage relation is just ğ‘“ğ‘£fâ¢(v)f(v) , once a node is â€œturned on it cannot return to the rest potential ğ‘£0v=0v=0. Therefore we expect the behavior of the solution at any node to be monotone increasing, that is, the solution to (2.10)- (2.11) represents a traveling front solution to (2.5)-(2.6).
3. Solution approximation outside the fixed interval
In this paper the class of problems of interest is
ğ‘¡-âˆ<t<+âˆ-\infty<t<+\infty, with ğ‘£0vâ¢(-âˆ)=0v(-\infty)=0, ğ‘£1vâ¢(+âˆ)=1v(+\infty)=1.

Here f is superscriptğ¶101C1â¢[0,1]C^{1}[0,1] and satisfies formulae-sequenceğ‘“00formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘“â€²00ğ‘“10fâ¢(0)=0,fâ€²â¢(0)<0,fâ¢(1)=0f(0)=0,f^{\prime}(0)<0,f(1)=0 and superscriptğ‘“â€²10fâ€²â¢(1)<0f^{\prime}(1)<0. We will later specialize to an f of the form given in Sect. 2. The constant delay must be found simultaneously with the solution. 4. The finite difference and interpolation schemes
Consider the following nonlinear mixed-delay problem

formulae-sequenceğ‘‘ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘‘ğ‘¡ğ‘“ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğœ2ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğœğ¿ğ‘¡ğ¿dâ¢vâ¢(t)dâ¢t=fâ¢(vâ¢(t))+vâ¢(t-Ï„)-2â¢vâ¢(t)+vâ¢(t+Ï„),-Lâ‰¤tâ‰¤L\displaystyle\frac{dv(t)}{dt}=f(v(t))+v(t-\tau)-2v(t)+v(t+\tau)\ ,\ -L\leq t\leq L,
with the following condition

This equation is defined in a fixed interval, where f is nonlinear and ğ‘“0ğ‘“10fâ¢(0)=fâ¢(1)=0f(0)=f(1)=0. Since the equation is autonomous, time translates of solutions are also solutions. To fix the phase of the solution, we impose condition (4.2).

We use a fixed, uniform step size â„hh in this scheme. We divided ğ¿ğ¿[-L,L][-L,\ L] into N equal size subintervals, letting formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—ğ¿ğ‘—â„ğ‘—012â‹¯ğ‘tj=-L+jâ¢h,j=0,1,2,â‹¯,Nt_{j}=-L+jh,j=0,1,2,\cdots,N, where ğ‘2ğ¿â„N=2â¢L/hN=2L/h and approximate ğ‘£subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—vâ¢(tj)v(t_{j}) by subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—vjv_{j}. We adopt a fourth-order scheme to approximate the derivative term. From 4, we have
for some ğœğœğ‘¡2â„ğ‘¡2â„Î¶,Î¶âˆˆ(t-2â¢h,t+2â¢h)\zeta,\zeta\in(t-2h,\ t+2h) .
Thus, we have for the derivative term

superscriptğ‘£â€²subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—112â„subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—28subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—18subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—2vâ€²â¢(tj)=112â¢hâ¢(vj-2-8â¢vj-1+8â¢vj+1-vj+2)v^{\prime}(t_{j})=\displaystyle\frac{1}{12h}(v_{j-2}-8v_{j-1}+8v_{j+1}-v_{j+2}) .

For ğ‘—0j=0j=0 and ğ‘—1j=1j=1, terms subscriptğ‘£2v-2v_{-2} and subscriptğ‘£1v-1v_{-1} appear on the right-hand side of (4.3). In these cases, we use the approximate formula (3.14) for ğ‘¡ğ¿2â„t=-L-2â¢ht=-L-2h and ğ‘¡ğ¿â„t=-L-ht=-L-h to approximate these terms. Similarly, for ğ‘—ğ‘1j=N-1j=N-1 and ğ‘—ğ‘j=Nj=N, terms subscriptğ‘£ğ‘1vN+1v_{N+1} and subscriptğ‘£ğ‘2vN+2v_{N+2} appear on the right-hand side of (4.3). We use (3.19) for ğ‘¡ğ¿â„t=L+ht=L+h and ğ‘¡ğ¿2â„t=L+2â¢ht=L+2h to approximate these terms.

To approximate the delayed and the advanced terms in (4.1), we use cubic interpolation. Let ğ‘€delimited-[]ğœâ„M=[Ï„/h]M=[\tau/h], where delimited-[]ğ‘¥[x][x] means the integer part of x, and let ğ‘Ÿğœğ‘€â„r=Ï„-Mâ¢hr=\tau-Mh; note that ğ‘Ÿ0râ‰¥0r\geq 0. Then ğ‘¡ğœt-Ï„t-\tau lies between ğ‘¡ğ‘€â„â„t-Mâ¢h-ht-Mh-h and ğ‘¡ğ‘€â„t-Mâ¢ht-Mh. We use the cubic formula

ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğœsubscriptğ¶4ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘€â„2â„subscriptğ¶3ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘€â„â„subscriptğ¶2ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘€â„subscriptğ¶1ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘€â„â„9superscriptâ„4324superscriptğ‘“fragmentsâŸ¨4)ğœvâ¢(t-Ï„)=C4â¢vâ¢(t-Mâ¢h-2â¢h)+C3â¢vâ¢(t-Mâ¢h-h)+C2â¢vâ¢(t-Mâ¢h)+C1â¢vâ¢(t-Mâ¢h+h)+9â¢h4324â¢fâŸ¨4)â¢(Î¶)v(t-\tau)=C_{4}v(t-Mh-2h)+C_{3}v(t-Mh-h)+C_{2}v(t-Mh)+C_{1}v(t-Mh+h)+% \displaystyle\frac{9h^{4}}{324}f^{\langle 4)}(\zeta) , for some ğœğœğ‘¡ğ‘€â„2â„ğ‘¡ğ‘€â„â„Î¶,Î¶âˆˆ(t-Mâ¢h-2â¢h,t-Mâ¢h+h)\zeta,\zeta\in(t-Mh-2h,\ t-Mh+h) ,
where the subscriptğ¶ğ‘–CiC_{i}â€™s are constants, given by
Thus, we have for the delayed term

ğ‘£subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—ğœsubscriptğ¶4subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘€2subscriptğ¶3subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘€1subscriptğ¶2subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘€subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘€1vâ¢(tj-Ï„)â‰ˆC4â¢vj-M-2+C3â¢vj-M-1+C2â¢vj-M+C1â¢vj-M+1v(t_{j}-\tau)\approx C_{4}v_{j-M-2}+C_{3}v_{j-M-1}+C_{2}v_{j-M}+C_{1}v_{j-M+1}.
When terms on the right-hand side of (4.5) have negative indices, formula (3.14) is used to approximate these terms. Similarly, we have for the advanced term

ğ‘£subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–ğœsubscriptğ¶4subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘€2subscriptğ¶3subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘€1subscriptğ¶2subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘€subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘€1vâ¢(ti+Ï„)â‰ˆC4â¢vj+M+2+C3â¢vi+M+1+C2â¢vj+M+C1â¢vj+M-1v(t_{i}+\tau)\approx C_{4}v_{j+M+2}+C_{3}v_{i+M+1}+C_{2}v_{j+M}+C_{1}v_{j+M-1},
and when terms on the right-hand side of (4.6) have indices exceeding N, formula (3.19) is used to approximate these terms.

By using (4.3) to (4.6) to replace the derivative, delayed and advanced terms in the equation (4.1), the approximation scheme has a local truncation error of order four. The discretized version of (4.1) is then

In the system (4.7), the subscriptğ‘£jvjv_{\mathrm{j}}â€™s for ğ‘—0j<0j<0 are functions of subscriptğ‘£0v0v_{0}, and are evaluated by using (3.14) with italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘£0Ïµ=v0\epsilon=v_{0}, and neglecting the terms ğ‘‚superscriptitalic-Ïµ4Oâ¢(Ïµ4)O(\epsilon^{4}) . The subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—vjv_{j}â€™s for ğ‘—ğ‘j>Nj>N are functions of subscriptğ‘£ğ‘vNv_{N}, and are evaluated by using (3.19) with subscriptitalic-Ïµ1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ïµ+=1-vN\epsilon_{+}=1-v_{N} and neglecting the terms ğ‘‚superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµ4Oâ¢(Ïµ+4)O(\epsilon_{+}^{4}) .
In addition to the ğ‘1N+1N+1 equations in (4.7), there is the condition
subscriptğ‘£ğ‘0.50vN,-0.5=0v_{N},-0.5=0, where superscriptğ‘â€²delimited-[]ğ‘2Nâ€²=[N/2]N^{\prime}=[N/2]
which replaces (4.2), and in addition to the ğ‘1N+1N+1 unknowns subscriptğ‘£0subscriptğ‘£1â‹¯subscriptğ‘£ğ‘v0,v1,â‹¯,vNv_{0},v_{1},\cdots,v_{N} there is the unknown delay ğœÏ„.\tau.
5. Solution of the discretized system

There are many possible ways of solving the system (4.7), (4.8) for subscriptğ‘£0subscriptğ‘£1v0,v1v_{0},v_{1}, . . . , subscriptğ‘£ğ‘vN,v_{N}, and ğœÏ„\tau. If the Newton-Raphson scheme were used directly, the approximate ğœÏ„\tau would vary in each iteration step, and the coefficient matrix might vary in bandwidth because the integer ğ‘€MM and the coefficients formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1â‹¯4Ck,k=1,â‹¯,4C_{k},k=1,\cdots,4 depend upon ğœÏ„\tau. To avoid the potential for discontinuous change in ğ‘€MM and the subscriptğ¶ğ‘˜CkC_{k}â€™s during the iteration, we designed a nested iteration scheme in which ğœÏ„\tau is fixed during the inner loop. The outer loop is the solution of an equation ğ‘”ğœ0gâ¢(Ï„)=0g(\tau)=0 by the secant method, where the function ğ‘”ğœgâ¢(Ï„)g(\tau) is defined as follows:
Definition ofğ‘”ğœgâ¢(Ï„)g(\tau) . For fixed ğœÏ„\tau, we solve the system of ğ‘1N+1N+1 equations
for ğ‘—01â‹¯superscriptğ‘â€²1j=0,1,â‹¯,Nâ€²-1j=0,1,\cdots,N^{\prime}-1
for ğ‘—superscriptğ‘â€²1â‹¯ğ‘j=Nâ€²+1,â‹¯,Nj=N^{\prime}+1,\cdots,N
for subscriptğ‘£0subscriptğ‘£1â‹¯subscriptğ‘£ğ‘v0,v1,â‹¯,vNv_{0},v_{1},\cdots,v_{N}. Then, we define ğ‘”ğœabsentgâ¢(Ï„)=g(\tau)=left- hand side of (4.7) for ğ‘—superscriptğ‘â€²j=Nâ€².j=N^{\prime}.

This particular definition of ğ‘”ğœgâ¢(Ï„)g(\tau) was arrived at after a certain amount of numerical experimentation. Unsuccessful attempts were made to solve the system (4.7) directly, and we tried to solve a modified version of (4.7) with the first equation replaced by a phase-fixing condition subscriptğ‘£0absentv0=v_{0}=constant which was found to be ineffective. The system (5.1) applies the phase-fixing condition to the component subscriptğ‘£superscriptğ‘ğ‘ŸvNrv_{N^{r}} where it was found to be effective. Note that replacing the Eq. (5.1) for ğ‘—superscriptğ‘â€²j=Nâ€²j=N^{\prime} with the equation subscriptğ‘£superscriptğ‘â€²0.50vNâ€²-0.5=0v_{N^{\prime}}-0.5=0 preserves the band structure of the Jacobian matrix.

To approximate a solution to this nonlinear system (5.1), we use the Newton- Raphson scheme 5. Given the initial approximation superscriptğ‘‰0V0V^{0}, a sequence of iterates formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘£0ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘£1ğ‘˜â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘˜0â€…1â‹¯{Vk=(v0k,v1k,â€¦,vNk),k=0,â€…1,â‹¯}\{V^{k}=\ (v_{0}^{k},\ v_{1}^{k},\ \ldots\ ,\ v_{N}^{k}),\ k=0,\ 1,\cdots\} is generated. This sequence converges to the solution provided that the superscriptğ‘‰0V0V^{0} is sufficiently close to the solution and the Jacobian matrix, J, is nonsingular at the solution.

The Jacobian matrix for the system (5.1) is a banded matrix with band width 2ğ‘€52â¢M+52M+5. In the numerical scheme, the Jacobian matrix was approximated by one-sided numerical differencing. The known band structure of the matrix was used to minimize the number of function evaluations required, and a banded matrix solver LEQT2B from the IMSL9 10 was used to solve the linear systems at each stage in the Newton-Raphson iteration.
ff\mathrm{f}. Continuation method
In the class of problems (3.1) we are considering, we have a test problem which we can solve exactly. This is (3.1) with the following expression for f:

. The solution to (3.1), (6.1) is formulae-sequenceğ‘£ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡2ğ‘¡ğ‘…vâ¢(t)=(1+tanhâ¡(t))/2,tâˆˆRv(t)=(1+\tanh(t))/2,t\in R, and ğœsuperscript1italic-Ï‘Ï„=tanh-1â¡(Ï‘)\tau=\tanh^{-1}(\sqrt{\vartheta}) . We may use this information and the continuation method (see 719) to solve other problems within our class of problems. Because we are solving a large system of nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method, it is very difficult to determine the initial guess which is close to the solution. So we take advantage of the test problem and continuation method to approach the solution we want. The way we use the continuation method on our class of problems is as follows. Consider the problem (3.1) with any nonlinearity subscriptğ‘“ğ‘‘ğ‘£fdâ¢(v)f_{d}(v) in our general class of fâ€™s which represents our target problem for which we desire the solution. We embed this problem in a one-parameter family of problems
with formulae-sequenceğ‘£0ğ‘£1vâ¢(-âˆ)=0,vâ¢(âˆ)=1v(-\infty)=0,v(\infty)=1,
with subscriptğ‘“italic-Ï‘ğ‘£fÏ‘â¢(v)f_{\vartheta}(v) given by (6.1).

We compute solutions for ğ›¼Î±\alpha varying from ğ›¼1Î±=1\alpha=1 to ğ›¼0Î±=0\alpha=0. For ğ›¼1Î±=1\alpha=1, we are just solving the test problem for which the exact ğ‘£ğ‘¡vâ¢(t)v(t) and ğœÏ„\tau are known. This exact solution is used as the initial guess to solve the correspond discrete system (4.7). Once a problem for ğ›¼0Î±>0\alpha>0 is solved, we decrease ğ›¼Î±\alpha incrementally by Î”ğ›¼Î”â¢Î±\Delta\alpha and use the solution to previous problem as the initial approximation to obtain the solution to the current problem. When we have solved the problem for ğ›¼0Î±=0,\alpha=0, we are done.
We solved the problem (2.10) numerically by the scheme presented above on the CDC Cyber 815. We shall discuss the results in the next section.
7. Numerical results

In this section we present results of numerically solving (3.1) using a FORTRAN program which employs the method outlined in Sects. 3-6. To start with, we determine the accuracy of the method by applying our scheme to the test problem (6.1) with known solution. Then, we feed the continuation method with two different test problems from (6.1), whose solutions are also known so that we are sure of the accuracy of the continuation method. Having verified the convergence of our scheme with the continuation method, we solve our target problem (2.11), starting the continuation method from one test problem of the form (6.1). It is worth noting that we started the continuation method from three different test problems and for each case we approached to the target problem (2.11) and got the same solution. Then we consider the effects of parameter changes on the solution, and delay ğœÏ„\tau, of the Eq. (2.8) and (2.10).
Consider the following problem:
ğ‘¡-âˆ<t<+âˆ-\infty<t<+\infty with formulae-sequenceğ‘£0ğ‘£1vâ¢(-âˆ)=0,vâ¢(+âˆ)=1v(-\infty)=0,v(+\infty)=1,

where subscriptğ‘“italic-Ï‘fÏ‘f_{\vartheta} is given by (6.1). This will be referred to as our test problem since, as we mentioned above, we know the solution and delay ğœÏ„\tau a priori. We use the scheme described above. We pick up a italic-Ï‘131Ï‘âˆˆ(1/3,1)\vartheta\in(1/3,1) and replace the coefficients in Sect. 3 by their actual values. Choosing our test problem with italic-Ï‘0.35Ï‘=0.35\vartheta=0.35, we have, analytically, the delay subscriptğœğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡0.680136Ï„eâ¢xâ¢aâ¢câ¢t=0.680136\tau_{exact}=0.680136. For this problem we ran the program with formulae-sequenceâ„0.1formulae-sequenceğ‘41formulae-sequenceitalic-Ïµ0.001ğœƒ0.35h=0.1,N=41,Ïµ=0.001,Î¸=0.35h=0.1,N=41,\epsilon=0.001,\theta=0.35, and ğ¿2.0L=2.0L=2.0. Since the system is nonlinear, we provide the initial guess of the solution to the iteration procedure by furnishing the program ğ‘41N=41N=41 mesh point values which came from the exact solution. Additionally, we need to find out ğœÏ„\tau by the secant method. Given subscriptğœ1subscriptğœğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡0.001Ï„1=Ï„eâ¢xâ¢aâ¢câ¢t+0.001\tau_{1}=\tau_{exact}+0.001 and subscriptğœ2subscriptğœğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡0.001Ï„2=Ï„eâ¢xâ¢aâ¢câ¢t-0.001\tau_{2}=\tau_{exact}-0.001, the program proceeds to iterate until the norm in the inner loop was less than superscript101010-1010^{-10} and the norm of ğœÏ„\tau in the outer loop is less than superscript10810-8.10^{-8}. As the result, we obtained the solution, presented in Table 1, of the delay equation and ğœ0.6801398Ï„=0.6801398\tau=0.6801398 with the error between computed and exact delay being 3.5superscript1063.5Ã—10-63.5\times 10^{-6}. To check the accuracy and the stability of our scheme, we reduced h by one half, reran the program, and obtained ğœ0.6801364Ï„=0.6801364\tau=0.6801364, with the error being 1.6superscript1071.6Ã—10-71.6\times 10^{-7}. The solution of the second experiment and the exact solution are also included in Table 1 for comparison. Notice that we obtained the initial guess for ğ‘81N=81N=81 case by applying the cubic interpolation method to the solutions of ğ‘41N=41N=41 case. From Table 1, we conclude that the computed solution agrees with the exact solution to better than five digits. Moreover, since the difference between computed results of ğ‘41N=41N=41 and ğ‘81N=81N=81 is ğ‘‚superscript106Oâ¢(10-6)O(10^{-6}) which is within the error tolerance Osuperscript104Oâ¢(10-4)\mathrm{O}(10^{-4}) , we proceeded to use ğ‘41N=41N=41 in the rest of the calculations. We now test the numerical scheme in conjunction with the continuation method by applying it to (7.1) and (6.1) with ğœƒ0.35Î¸=0.35\theta=0.35 for the initial test problem, and ğœƒ0.45Î¸=0.45\theta=0.45 for the problem to be solved. We set ğ›¼1Î±=1\alpha=1 at the beginning, use the exact solution as initial guess for the problem, and choose a pair of numbers as the initial guesses of ğœÏ„\tau. The system is very sensitive and choosing too inaccurate a choice of inital guess of ğœÏ„\tau will cause the divergence of the solution. In the program run we set formulae-sequenceğ‘51formulae-sequenceğ‘0.05formulae-sequenceğ‘15.0â„0.2N=51,a=0.05,b=15.0,h=0.2N=51,a=0.05,b=15.0,h=0.2, and ğ¿5.0L=5.0L=5.0. For each run, once we obtain the solution and ğœÏ„\tau of the delay equation, we decreased ğ›¼Î±\alpha by 0.1 and executed the iteration again. The same procedure was repeated until ğ›¼0Î±=0.\alpha=0. The solution and ğœÏ„\tau obtained are given in Table 2. Comparison of the computed solution and the exact solution is given in Table 3. We ran the same experiment over, starting with different test problems to see how sensitive the continuation method was to changes in the test problem. The initial test problem we adopted was (7.1) with italic-Ï‘0.4Ï‘=0.4\vartheta=0.4. As predicted, it converged to the same ğœ0.81229647Ï„=0.81229647\tau=0.81229647 and we got the solution to agree with that of case ğœƒ0.35Î¸=0.35\theta=0.35 to better than 12 digits. In addition, from Table 3 we realize that the largest error is 0.94superscript1040.94Ã—10-40.94\times 10^{-4}. Therefore, we determined that the continuation method is accurate and in our experiment no matter which initial test problem we start with, we obtained the correct solution. We then applied our numerical approach to the problem (2.10) with ğ‘“ğ‘£fâ¢(v)f(v) presented in Sect. 2. The test problem employed is (6.1) with italic-Ï‘0.35Ï‘=0.35\vartheta=0.35. Running the program with formulae-sequenceğ‘0.05formulae-sequenceğ‘15formulae-sequenceâ„0.05ğ‘41a=0.05,b=15,h=0.05,N=41a=0.05,b=15,h=0.05,N=41, and ğ¿1L=1L=1, we obtained ğœ0.4351126Ï„=0.4351126\tau=0.4351126 and the solution, presented in Table 4, to the problem (2.10). Then we reran our program with italic-Ï‘0.40Ï‘=0.40\vartheta=0.40 and 0.425 respectively in (6.1). Comparing the results obtained from using different ğœƒÎ¸\thetaâ€™s, we realized that for all the test problems we chose, we got the same ğœÏ„\tau, and the approximate solutions computed by the method starting from different test problems agree with each other to better than 12 digits (by using a good matrix solver, LEQT2B in IMSL9, with accuracy of 12 digits). The ğ›¼ğœÎ±-Ï„\alpha-\tau relation graph for different ğœƒÎ¸\thetaâ€™s is exhibited in Fig. 3. The solution to (2.10) for ğœƒ0.40Î¸=0.40\theta=0.40 and 0.425 is included in Table 4 as well. To present the continuation procedure more clearly, the solution changes for different ğ›¼Î±\alphaâ€™s are shown in Fig. 4. The curves in [-2, 2] represent the graph for ğ›¼1Î±=1\alpha=1, 0.8, 0.6, 0.4, 0.2, 0.1 where ğ›¼1Î±=1\alpha=1 is the initial test problem and ğ›¼0Î±=0\alpha=0 is the target problem. Notice that the curves shrink and become more and more stiff as ğ›¼Î±\alpha decreases. Owing to the autonomous nature of this system, the program fixes the function value at ğ‘¡0t=0t=0, namely, ğ‘£00.5vâ¢(0)=0.5v(0)=0.5. According to the test results, we are convinced that in all cases the method will reliably give rise to solutions converging to the desired solution of (2.10).

Parameter changes will affect the behavior of the delay ğœÏ„\tau and the solution to the delay equation (2.10). Now we introduce some experiments of changing parameters a,b,R and ğ¶CC and see what happens to the delay ğœÏ„\tau and equation solution. We will explain the behavior changes from the physiological point of view as well. We first examined how changes in the value of the threshold potential affected the rise time and the conduction speed of action potential. We fixed all other parameters by letting formulae-sequenceâ„0.05formulae-sequenceğ‘41ğ‘15h=0.05,N=41,b=15h=0.05,N=41,b=15, and ğ¿1L=1L=1, and allowed the variable a to vary from 0.01 to 0.12 with increments of 0.01. As a decreases, the solution ğ‘£ğ‘¡vâ¢(t)v(t) becomes steeper in the middle and flatter on the ends. The change is shown in Fig. 5. This means the rise time of the membrane potential is faster for lower threshold potential. We cannot directly compare this behavior to experimental observations because it is difficult experimentally to determine a precise value for threshold potential in real nodal membrane. Next consider the effect of threshold changes on the behavior of the conduction speed. From Table 5, we observe that the larger is, the larger ğœÏ„\tau is. That is, all other parameters being fixed, an axon with higher threshold potential has lower conduction speed since the conduction speed is inversely proportional to internodal delay ğœÏ„\tau. Hence, axons with higher threshold potential have lower conduction speeds and slower rise times. This gives indirect consistent behavior to some experimental findings of Paintal 17 and Coppin and Jack (unpublished observations, see Jack et al. 11), who found that action potentials (in myelinated fibers of cats) with slower conduction speeds have slower rise times. Since the model dynamics at the nodes is so simplified, we can make only qualitative comparisons with experiments, not quantitative ones.

Next we study the relationship between the strength of ionic current density, ğ‘bb, to the conduction speed and rise time of the membrane potential. We fix formulae-sequenceâ„0.05formulae-sequenceğ‘41ğ‘0.05h=0.05,N=41,a=0.05h=0.05,N=41,a=0.05, and ğ¿1.0L=1.0L=1.0, and let ğ‘bb vary from 10 to 20 in unit increments. We notice that the smaller b is, the slower the solution rises (see Fig. 6). More specifically, if the strength of the ionic current density is lessened, the rise time of the membrane potential is slower, and ğœÏ„\tau is larger. Hence the conduction speed is larger when the strength of ionic current density is larger. Roughly interpreted, increasing the membrane conductance increases the conduction speed. We do not have experiments on myelinated axons to compare to this result directly, but it is known in studies on unmyelinated axons that increasing membrane conductances, for example imposing a higher density of sodium channels, lead to higher conduction speeds. Therefore all qualitative results seem to be consistent with experimental evidence as far as we can determine.

In the following, we study the behavior of the delay ğœÏ„\tau and the solution to (2.9) under the control of axoplasmic nodal resistance ğ‘…RR and modal capacitance C, where the model equation becomes

To determine qualitatively the relationship between the nodal capacitance, C, to the conduction speed and rise time of the membrane potential, we fixed the nodal resistance ğ‘…RR equal to 1 and let ğ¶CC vary from 0.7 to 1.3 in increments of 0.1. As seen in Fig. 7, the smaller ğ¶CC is, the faster the solution rises. This means that the rise time of the membrane potential is faster for lower nodal capacitance. From Table 6, we observe that when ğ¶CC increases ğœÏ„\tau increases. That is, if all other parameters are fixed, an axon with higher nodal capacitance has slower conduction speed. This is consistent with our intuition and known results on unmyelinated fibers that increasing the membrane capacitance tends to decrease conduction velocity. This result has also been verified by Moore et al. 15, who numerically examined the sensitivity of propagation speed on nodal capacity (see his Fig. 2). In their paper, they modelled the myelinated axon basically like an unmyelinated axon with spatially varying coefficients. Specifically, they allowed current leakage across the internodal regions, but this does not affect the qualitative dependence of conduction speed on nodal capacitance. It will, of course, have a significant quantitative eflect. The above two observations of our model are also consistent with the previous observation that slower speed wave fronts have slow rise times. Now consider the same model with the nodal capacity ğ¶CC fixed and resistivity R allowed to vary. For convenience we let ğ¶1C=1C=1 and varied R between 0.5 and 2.5. The numerical tests show us that when R decreases, the rise time of the solution decreases (see Fig. 8). In other words, the rise time of the membrane potential is faster for smaller nodal resistance. Again we observe from Table 6 that as ğ‘…RR increases, so does ğœÏ„\tau. Hence we conclude that the higher nodal resistance will give rise to slower conduction speed and slower rise time in the action potential. Again this is consistent with the numerical results of Moore et al. 15, as well as previous work on unmyelinated axon modeling.

In summary, we have studied an extremely simple model of nerve conduction for myelinated axons and have found the parameter dependence results consistent with those of previous models and experiments. Of greater interest is our demonstration that the advance and delay terms which arise as a consequence of the traveling wave hypothesis in a saltatory model of myelinated nerve fiber can be treated explicitly, without considering other diffusion approximations. Because the myelinated membranes do allow some transmembrane current to leak across, we have modified the above model to account for this current, and in particular, to consider the effect of myelin resistivity and capacitance. This work will be reported elsewhere.
